support_summary: ATXN3 and Ufd1, a cofactor of VCP/p97, bind to VCP in a mutually exclusive manner, indicating a direct and regulatory interaction within the VCP complex.

functions.cellular_process: ATXN3 and the VCP/p97 cofactor Ufd1 (part of the Ufd1-Npl4 dimer) compete for binding to the N-domain of VCP/p97. The binding of ATXN3 to VCP/p97 displaces the Ufd1-Npl4 complex, thereby altering the composition of the VCP/p97 complex and its function in the Endoplasmic Reticulum-Associated Degradation (ERAD) pathway.
functions.effect_description: By competitively binding to VCP/p97, ATXN3 reduces the association of the VCP-Ufd1-Npl4 complex with ubiquitinated ERAD substrates. This inhibits the VCP-dependent extraction (retrotranslocation) of misfolded proteins from the ER, leading to their accumulation and a decrease in their subsequent degradation by the proteasome.
biological_consequence: ATXN3 binds to the N-domain of VCP/p97 → Ufd1-Npl4 complex is displaced from VCP/p97 → The VCP/p97 complex has reduced association with ubiquitinated ERAD substrates → Retrotranslocation of misfolded proteins from the ER to the cytosol is inhibited → Degradation of ERAD substrates is decreased, leading to their accumulation in the ER.
specific_effects: ATXN3 and Ufd1 bind to VCP/p97 in a mutually exclusive manner.
ATXN3 expression decreases the amount of Ufd1 associated with VCP/p97.
ATXN3 inhibits the retrotranslocation of ERAD substrates from the ER in a reconstituted system.
The interaction modulates the flow of substrates through the ERAD pathway.

evidence.paper_title: Ataxin-3 binds VCP/p97 and regulates retrotranslocation of ERAD substrates
evidence.relevant_quote: AT3 and Ufd1 bind VCP in a mutually exclusive manner; AT3 decreases the interaction of VCP with Ufd1 as well as with ubiquitylated proteins. Using a reconstituted system, AT3 inhibits retrotranslocation of an ERAD substrate from the ER. These data suggest that a normal function of AT3 is to regulate flow through the ERAD pathway by modulating VCP-dependent extraction of proteins from the ER.

mechanism: ATXN3 and the VCP/p97 cofactor Ufd1 (part of the Ufd1-Npl4 dimer) compete for binding to the N-domain of VCP/p97. The binding of ATXN3 to VCP/p97 displaces the Ufd1-Npl4 complex, thereby altering the composition of the VCP/p97 complex and its function in the Endoplasmic Reticulum-Associated Degradation (ERAD) pathway.
effect: By competitively binding to VCP/p97, ATXN3 reduces the association of the VCP-Ufd1-Npl4 complex with ubiquitinated ERAD substrates. This inhibits the VCP-dependent extraction (retrotranslocation) of misfolded proteins from the ER, leading to their accumulation and a decrease in their subsequent degradation by the proteasome.
summary: ATXN3 inhibits Ufd1 to modulate vcp/p97 complex assembly, ultimately affecting degradation of erad substrates is decreased, leading to their accumulation in the er.

evidence.paper_title: Ataxin-3 binds VCP/p97 and regulates retrotranslocation of ERAD substrates
evidence.relevant_quote: AT3 and Ufd1 bind VCP in a mutually exclusive manner; AT3 decreases the interaction of VCP with Ufd1 as well as with ubiquitylated proteins. Using a reconstituted system, AT3 inhibits retrotranslocation of an ERAD substrate from the ER. These data suggest that a normal function of AT3 is to regulate flow through the ERAD pathway by modulating VCP-dependent extraction of proteins from the ER.
